items.title: InfoMaven, an Introduction
items.author: Jack Stephenson
items.description:
For anyone that’s read George Orwell’s classic 1984, the idea of “Techno Dystopia” is familiar. In 1984, technology has become so advanced that it has spawned a creed of ideological simplicity. The inhabitants of Orwell’s world suffer a bleak, culture-less existence.

Plainly speaking, a technological dystopia is a society in which technological advances pass a certain point, beyond which technology ceases to better society, and instead begins to impede daily life. In the words of Jaron Lanier, technological advancements will eventually reach a point of “singularity”, which once reached will mark the end of the world as we know it.

Whereas my fear is not as extreme, and I do not think we are on the verge of the end, I have created this blog to share certain instances in which technologies have surpassed their positive societal inputs, and instead are actively detrimental to their users. It is my hope that with greater mindfulness of how new technologies affect us, we may avoid as many of these negative side effects as possible. I believe that currently, the study of human-technology interaction is far behind the rate of innovation, and in order to prevent “the singularity”, we must dedicate as much effort to understanding new technologies as we dedicate to their creation.

The “Information Era” in which we currently live is a world of endless possibilities, at the same time frightening and intriguing. Cars now drive themselves, relationships can be maintained across infinite distances, breakthroughs in medical science are achieved at impossible speeds. Unfortunately, with these gifts come tragedies. Hopefully, with more emphasis on the study of Information, we may navigate the treacherous pitfalls of innovation while maintaining its breakneck speed.

In my opinion, our current state of being is shameful. Governments surveil their own people with perverse intensity. Generations of children grow up at the mercy of ever-changing social media platforms, whose sociological side effects we barely understand. Almost every adult in America lives in a state of constant distraction and anxiety, tethered to the glowing screen in their hand. The lawlessness of the internet propagates the spread of misinformation, leading to witch-hunts and instances of primitive “mob-mentality”. Without dramatic change, this dystopia that is forming in the wake of the information age may be our destruction.

Citations:

· Lanier, Jaron. “You Are Not a Gadget.” Google Books. N.p., n.d. Web. 14 Nov. 2016.

items.title: Big Brother is Watching You
items.author: Jack Stephenson
items.description:
(and so is google, amazon, and the cops)

Following the release of Amazon’s new Echo line of smart-home devices, I decided it was time to ditch the twenty-foot aux cord I had been using for my stereo system and opt for a more tech-forward solution. As well as a Bluetooth receiver, the fifty-dollar puck serves as a home for Amazon’s digital assistant “Alexa”. Alexa works quite well in execution, allowing me to tell her which songs to play — at what volume, as well as make purchases on amazon, set my alarm, and other time-saving features.

As the concept of a smart-home grew on me, I explored googles alternative, the Google Home, which as well as matching most of Echo’s features, also offers the ability to learn. I was amazed, but before I returned my Echo and ordered a Home, I decided to give Google Assistant a spin on Google’s recently released Allo messaging platform. Instead of asking Alexa to perform a task, I instead was able to hold short conversations with Google Assistant. With each conversation, Google Assistant promised to learn more about the way I communicate, as well as my daily habits, and personal preferences. As cool as it is to “talk” to Google Assistant, it was little unnerving how personal it gets. Whereas I am not one to don the proverbial tinfoil hat, I wondered where everything Google Assistant learned about me would end up. Another important note: both devices are always on. Always listening.

A google search led me to an article on The Verge, which shed some light on the subject. Apparently at Google’s annual I/O conference, Google promised users that Allo would be a “step forward for privacy”, offering end-to-end encryption and transitional message storing. However, with the release of the app, Google silently backed-off on many of these features. It turns out that law enforcement agencies will be able to subpoena allo chats, giving them access to everything Google Assistant knows about you (whereabouts, text messages, etc…). The Verge’s article is brief, but potent — relating just the facts and allowing its readers to draw their own conclusions. At this time the details behind both the information gathering capabilities of Allo and its legal ramifications are shrouded in uncertainty. Google’s deceptive tactics suggest that the Allo team is aware that their project over-steps some users’ boundaries, something I am not okay with.

Google’s frightening privacy violations point back to the idea that new technologies such as Google Home contribute to a “goldfish bowl society”(Froomkin, 2015). A. Michael Froomkin warns in his Journal of Self-Regulation and Regulation entry that “The Internet plus cellphones, plus sensors, equals basically a goldfish bowl society, and we are the goldfish”. It is frightening to know that in a society where so much of our daily lives rely on internet communication, we have no real way of knowing who’s watching, or even what they are able to see.

Though I know Alexa is always listening, I am comforted by the fact that she’s just dumb enough to protect me from the legal ramifications of what I tell her. Always-listening is one thing, always-remembering is something else all-together.

Citations

· Froomkin, A. Michael. “From Anonymity to Identification.” Journal of Self-Regulation and Regulation 1 (2015): 130. Print.

· Brandom, Russel. “Google Backs off on Previously Announced Allo Privacy Feature.” The Verge. Vox Media, 21 Sept. 2016. Web. 31 Oct. 2016.

items.title: Who are you?
items.author: Jack Stephenson
items.description:
The desire to answer this unanswerable question is the force behind the journey to its answer. Much of our childhood and adolescent life is spent building our identity, so it’s easy to understand why roadblocks to identity formation are dangerous. Since the advent of social media, experts have pondered its effects on adolescent identity development. An article by Rachel Ehmke of the Child Mind Institute examines whether or not social media and smartphone usage promotes anxiety and lowers self-esteem.

The article, which is as rife with expert opinions as it is well-written, serves as an attempt to warn parents of the pitfalls of social media and smartphone use. Ehmke explains that “likes” on social media sites provide insecure adolescents with “actual polled data on how much people like them”. This drives teens to actively, and at times obsessively, shape their online persona. Teens spend hours selecting pictures, writing bios, and cultivating a network of “friends” — all in an effort to make their social personas more appealing. The tragedy of this, as Ehmke points out, is that these teens compare their actual lives to the curated personas of those around them. To compare all of ones positive and negative experiences and attributes with only the positives of those around them is to set oneself up for certain disappointment, and destruction of self-esteem. A snippet of Sherry Turkles book Alone Together, demonstrates this phenomenon. Upon creating her Facebook profile, fourteen-year-old Mona expressed her worry to Turkle that when faced with other girl’s profiles, Mona worried that she didn’t “have enough of a social life to make herself sound interesting”.

Furthermore, Ehmke details how smartphones provide teens with constant social connection, and a distinct lack of important alone time. According to one Dr. Wick, adolescents need “time alone to regroup, replenish and just chill out. When you don’t have that, it’s easy to become emotionally depleted, fertile ground for anxiety to breed.” Turkle enforces this point, stating that “young people live in a state of waiting for connection”. Personally, I often feel the same way. In fact, I’ve probably checked my phone half a dozen times since the beginning of this post, and most of those times weren’t prompted by a notification buzz — simply my desire to connect.

It saddens me to think that my children will most likely grow up under these same circumstances. I feel that however toxic, social media is here to stay. As to the question of “Techno Utopianism”, I personally feel that social media, and the smartphone does more harm than good for adolescent users. It’s a truly depressing world where children are under constant pressure to lie to their peers, and to themselves, about who they really are.

Citations:

· Turkle, Sherry. “Growing up Tethered.” Alone Together: Why We Expect More from Technology and Less from Each Other. N.p.: n.p., n.d. 171–86. Print.

· Ehmke, Rachel. “How Using Social Media Affects Teenagers.” Child Mind Institute. Child Mind Institute, n.d. Web. 01 Nov. 2016.

items.title: Witch Hunts in the Age of Cognitive Surplus
items.author: Jack Stephenson
items.description:
In 2013, two terrorists detonated improvised explosive devices at the finish line of the Boston Marathon. People across the United States erupted in a fury of patriotism and outrage. An article on Business Insider details the “reddit witch-hunt” that ensued. Three days after the attack, police had yet to apprehend the two suspects, and grainy photographs of the suspected bombers were released on live television. Almost immediately, members of social-news aggregation site “Reddit” created a thread dedicated to aiding the police in their manhunt. In the spirit of collaboration and justice, redditors worked around the clock to search the internet for any trace of the bombers identity.

About a month earlier, a different internet manhunt had taken place. In March of 2013, a student at Brown University named Sunil Tripathi suddenly went missing. Sunil’s friends and family created a facebook page, “Help Us Find Sunil Tripathi”, hoping to spread awareness of Sunil’s disappearance. The page contained messages of love and hope, prayers for Sunil’s safety.

Somehow, Sunil’s page found its way into the hands of one of the redditors involved with the Boston Bomber search. A comparison of Sunil’s photo and the photos released on television of the bombers was posted on 4Chan and Reddit, and in the excitement, Sunil was falsely “identified” as the bomber. Immediately, Sunil’s page was bombarded with hateful comments and accusations, prompting its removal by Sunil’s family. As the reddit witch-hunt gained traction, major twitter users spread Sunil’s name across the internet, fueling the hype behind his identification. Though Sunil’s name was ultimately cleared on live television, in only a few hours his family had already received hundreds of death threats, anti-islamic messages, and hateful phone calls. Despite apologies from journalists and bloggers who had aggregated Sunil’s false identification, the emotional toll on Sunil’s family was devastating.

Business Insider’s article tells the story of the witch-hunt, but really doesn’t capture its implications. In my opinion, the worst part of this sort of witch-hunt is that making such a baseless accusation has zero consequences for the accuser. The anonymity of the internet arms people with the power to wreck lives in an instant, feeding into an unhealthy lynch-mob mentality. The Boston Bombing witch-hunt is an example of cognitive surplus gone wrong. Clay Shirky, in his book Cognitive Surplus: Creativity and Generosity in a Connected Age, praises the advent of Web 2.0 as a “revolution… centered on the shock of the inclusion of amateurs as producers, where we no longer need to ask for help or permission from professionals to say things in public.” User generated content is cool; everybody loves cat-pictures and youtube videos, but to negate the drawbacks of cognitive surplus is foolish. When reputations are on the line, and people will do anything for on-line recognition, a little professional fact-checking could go a long way. For Sunil’s family, and others affected by witch-hunts, this is no “Techno-Utopia”.

Citations:

· Shirky, Clay. Cognitive Surplus: Creativity and Generosity in a Connected Age. New York: Penguin, 2010. Print.

· Shontell, Alyson. “What It’s Like When Reddit Wrongly Accuses Your Loved One Of Murder.” Business Insider. Business Insider, Inc, 26 July 2013. Web. 31 Oct. 2016.

items.title: Smart Phones: Who Uses Who?
items.author: Jack Stephenson
items.description:
You have a smartphone in your pocket, I can almost guarantee it. In fact, it is becoming impossible to function without one. From my own experience, going without my smartphone for even a day not only puts a strain on my relationships; it stresses me out. My smartphone is no longer an accessory to my daily life, a tool for organization and convenience, but an integral part of my social network, education, and overall well being. I’ve found it difficult to pinpoint my feelings towards my phone, but I have realized that regardless of my opinion on my smartphone, using it is very addicting.

An article I discovered, on webmd of all places, details this addiction and its affects on daily life. A few of the statistics provided by freelance journalist Susan Davis help illuminate this phenomenon. According to a study at the Harvard Business School, 44% of adults would experience “a great deal of anxiety” if they couldn’t access their smartphone for a week. Additionally, she states that the average user checks his or her device an average of 35 times a day. Compared to an average one or two email checks a day, this number is massive. Davis continued on to quote Nicholas Carr, author of The Shallows: What the Internet is Doing to our Brains. Carr claims that smartphones, due to their easy accessibility, provide users with an “environment of almost constant interruptions and distractions”. Furthermore, Carr states that it is nearly impossible for humans to resist our innate desire to know everything that goes on around us, and therefore it is next to impossible to resist the temptation to constantly check one’s smartphone. Davis concludes her piece with a bulleted list of suggestions for how a user can resist their smartphone; all centered around self-discipline.

Whether or not we live in an age of “Information Utopia” or “Information Dystopia” is hard to pinpoint. The negative side effects to 21st century technology, however, are not. Clearly our newfound cultural obsession with our phones is negative. Without opportunities for self reflection and true relaxation, we are left to stress constantly about augmenting our media intake. A sentiment from one of our readings; Malcom McCullough’s book Ambient Commons: Attention in the Age of Embodied Information, captures this phenomenon well. McCullough presents the image of “a retreat from an annoying set of glowing rectangles at work to a soothing set of glowing rectangles at home. There might be advantages to unplugging altogether for a while, but people seem to put a higher priority on regaining control of their media first.” (51) This article, as well as what we have learned in class, made me feel almost guilty in a way. I am at the same time both mindful of the negative side effects to information overload and attention division, and unable to mend my personal habits. I, like Davis’ 70% of adults check my phone first thing in the morning, and like another 56% check it within an hour of going to sleep. In-between I am a slave to the buzz of my iPhone, checking my phone in the middle of conversations, lectures, and genuine life-experiences. The smartphone, in my eyes, is a burden that our current society forces upon us, with no alternative route. Smartphone addiction has become a part of life.

Citations:

· Davis, Susan. “Smartphone Addiction: Managing Your Phone Usage Time.”WebMD. WebMD, 21 June 2012. Web. 31 Oct. 2016.

· McCullough, Malcolm. “Attention.” Ambient Commons: Attention in the Age of Embodied Information. N.p.: n.p., n.d. 46–67. Print.
